Numerous video games were released in 2016. New hardware came out as well, albeit largely refreshed and updated versions of consoles in the PlayStation 4 Pro, PlayStation4 Slim, and Xbox One S. Commercially available virtual reality headsets were released in much greater numbers and at much lower price points than the enthusiast-only virtual reality headsets of earlier generations. Top-rated games originally released in 2016 included Uncharted 4: A Thief's End, Inside, Overwatch, Forza Horizon 3, NBA 2K17, Dark Souls III, and Battlefield 1.

Financial performance[edit]

Analysis firm SuperData estimated that the global video game software market brought in $91 billion in revenues in 2016; this was an increase over the $74 billion estimated for 2015, but SuperData noted that their 2016 estimates included a larger data set. Of the $91 billion, $41 billion was attributed to mobile gaming, particularly the titles Clash Royale and Pokémon Go, with the largest mobile gaming section in Asia with total revenues near $25 billion.[1] Personal computer gaming made up $34 billion, with $19 billion contributed from free-to-play games, and console games, retail and downloadable, were $26 and $6.6 billion, respectively.[2] The firm also identified that virtual reality (VR), professional video game sports, and streaming were still growing markets in the year.[2] DFC Intelligence reported similar numbers for revenues in the various sectors, and noted that mobile gaming revenues overtook both console and personal computer revenues in 2016.[3]

Newzoo estimated that $70.4 billion of video game revenues were made by the top 25 publicly-trading companies, led by Tencent ($10.2B), Sony ($7.9B), Activision Blizzard ($6.6B), Microsoft ($6.5B) and Apple, Inc. ($5.9B). The top ten companies brought in more than 54% of total revenues during 2016, up from 43% in 2015.[4]

IHS Markit estimated that worldwide revenue related to console hardware, software, and services was $34.7 billion, down about 2.5% from 2015; hardware sales were down from $12.8 billion to $10.5 billion, while software and service revenues were up. Sony held about 57% of the market share during 2016, followed by Microsoft and Nintendo.[5]

Within the United States, revenues from the video game industry in 2016 was estimated at $30.4 billion by the Entertainment Software Association and NPD Group, slightly up from 2015's $30.2 billion. Of that, $24.5 billion was spent on video game software, an increase of 6% from 2015. Digital purchases, which included full game purchases, downloadable content, game subscriptions, and mobile game microtransactions, made up 74% of this number, continuing a steady increase of digital sales over retail since 2010.[6] Sales were driven by the introduction of VR, Pokémon Go and Pokémon Sun and Moon, and the games Battlefield 1, Call of Duty: Infinite Warfare, Madden NFL 17, NBA 2K17 and Tom Clancy's The Division.[7]

Series with new entries and new intellectual property[edit]

Additional entries were released in numerous series in 2016, including new installments for the franchises Ace Attorney, Battlefield, Call of Duty, Civilization, Cossacks, Dark Souls, Dead Rising, Deus Ex, Dishonored, Doom, Far Cry, FIFA, Final Fantasy, Fire Emblem, Forza Horizon, Gears of War, Hearts of Iron, Hitman, Homefront, Homeworld, Kirby, Mafia, Mario Party, Master of Orion, Metroid, Mirror's Edge, Persona, Plants vs. Zombies: Garden Warfare, Pokémon, Ratchet & Clank, Shadow of the Beast, Shadow Warrior, Sonic the Hedgehog, Star Fox, Star Ocean, Street Fighter, Titanfall, Total War, Uncharted, Watch Dogs, XCOM and Zero Escape.

New and successful intellectual properties included Overwatch, Quantum Break, Tom Clancy's The Division and The Last Guardian, and indie titles such as Abzû, Hyper Light Drifter, Inside, No Man's Sky, Owlboy, Stardew Valley and The Witness.

January 4 Activision Blizzard announced that they had acquired Major League Gaming.[8]
6 Square Enix closed cloud gaming subsidiary Shinra Technologies.[9]
8 Marc Laidlaw, lead writer of the Half-Life series, retired from Valve Corporation.[10]
David Brevik, the CEO of Gazillion Entertainment, left the company.[11]
12 Electronic Arts introduced Origin Access, a new subscription service for Microsoft Windows.[12]
13 Leslie Benzies, producer and president of Rockstar North, left the company after a 16-month sabbatical. His positions were taken up by Aaron Garbut and Rob Nelson.[13]
16 Brian Horton, director of Rise of the Tomb Raider, left Crystal Dynamics for Infinity Ward.[14]
22 David Gaider, lead writer of Dragon Age, left BioWare.[15]
28 Bungie announced that Pete Parsons had replaced Harold Ryan as the company's president.[16]
GOG.com launched Games in Development, their own early access program.[17]
Sumo Digital announced their plan of establishing a new studio in Nottingham.[18]
29–31 PAX South 2016 held at the Henry B. Gonzalez Convention Center.[19]

GameTrailers video game website was closed.[21]
27 The Pokémon franchise celebrated its 20th anniversary.[22]
Unknown Ryan Barnard, game director of Tom Clancy's The Division, left Massive Entertainment for IO Interactive.[23]
March 7 Press Play, the developer of Max: The Curse of Brotherhood and Kalimba was closed by Microsoft Studios.[24]
9 Nexon acquired Big Huge Games, the developer of DomiNations.[25]
Riot Games acquired Radiant Entertainment, the developer of Rising Thunder.[26]
14–18 Game Developers Conference 2016 held in San Francisco, California.[27]
15 Jagex was acquired by Chinese mining company Shandong Honda.[28]
22 Bigpoint Games was acquired by Youzu Interactive.[29]
Evolution Studios, the developer of MotorStorm and Driveclub, was shut down by Sony Computer Entertainment.[30]
The Resident Evil franchise celebrated its 20th anniversary.[31]
24 Sony Computer Entertainment announced that they had founded a new studio, ForwardWorks to develop mobile games.[32]
31 n-Space, the developer of Sword Coast Legends, was closed.[33]
Sega completed its acquisition of Atlus. Future Atlus-developed titles localized for America will be published by Sega.[34]
April 1 Sony Computer Entertainment was merged with Sony Network Entertainment to form Sony Interactive Entertainment.[35]
5 Karthik and Guha Bala, founders of Vicarious Visions, left the company.[36]

18 GameStop announced GameTrust, a new publishing division.[39]
20 Microsoft announced the discontinuation of the production of Xbox 360.[40]
22 Tatsuya Minami, president of PlatinumGames, left the company.[41]
22–24 PAX East 2016 held at the Boston Convention and Exhibition Center.[42]
25 Patrice Desilets gained back the rights to 1666 Amsterdam and settled the lawsuit with Ubisoft.[43]
26 NIS America announced that they had cut ties with Atlus after Sega's acquisition of Atlus.[44]
SNK Playmore was restructured to form SNK.[45]
29 Lionhead Studios was closed by Microsoft Studios.[46]
May 10 Avalanche Software was shut down by parent company Disney Interactive Studios. Disney decided they would not self-publish any titles in the future, and instead rely on external partners.[47]
13 Yahoo! Games was shut down by Yahoo!.[48]
18 Electronic Arts announced that they had formed a new studio called Frostbite Lab.[49]
The creator of the Madden NFL series, Rich Hilleman, left Electronic Arts.[50]
IGN purchased assets of GameTrailers from Defy Media.[51]
30 Starbreeze Studios acquired the Payday franchise from 505 Games.[52]
June 1 Vivendi succeeded in Gameloft's hostile takeover, seizing control from the Guillemot brothers.[53]
2 Techland established a new publishing label called Techland Publishing.[54]
3 Aaron Linde, the writer of Battleborn, left Gearbox Software.[55]
6 Future Publishing purchased Imagine Publishing, the owner of GamesTM.[56]
10 Ubisoft Casablanca was closed by Ubisoft.[57]
12-14 Electronic Arts held their first fan-orientated public event named EA Play.[58]
14–16 E3 2016 was held at the Los Angeles Convention Center.[59]
21 Supercell, the developer of Clash of Clans, was acquired by Tencent for $8.6 billion.[60]
23 The Sonic the Hedgehog franchise celebrated its 25th anniversary.
July 1 Josh Mosqueira, the director of Diablo III, announced that he had left Blizzard Entertainment.[61]
5 Sega announced that they had acquired Endless Space developer Amplitude Studios.[62]
8 Adam Boyes, VP of third party relations & developer technology group of Sony Interactive Entertainment, departed from the company.[63]
11 Splash Damage, the developer of the two Enemy Territory games, was acquired by Chinese chicken meat company Leyou.[64]
19 Dino Patti, co-founder of Playdead, departed the company.[65]
August 3–13 The International 2016, the second highest paying eSports tournament in history, was held at the KeyArena in Seattle.[66]
4–7 QuakeCon 2016 was held in Hilton Anatole in Dallas.[67]
5 Relentless Software, the developer of the Buzz! series, shut down.[68]
12 Nordic Games, the company that acquired most THQ's franchises, rebranded to THQ Nordic.[69]
15–16 Game Developers Conference Europe 2016 was held in Cologne, Germany.
17–21 Gamescom 2016 held in Cologne, Germany.[70]
29 Independent developer Renegade Kid was replaced by two companies: Atooi (who owns all of Renegade Kid's 2D IPs) and Infinitizmo (which owns all of Renegade Kid's 3D IPs).[71]
September 2–5 PAX West 2016 held at the Washington State Convention Center.
13 Microsoft Studios launched Xbox Play Anywhere, a cross-play program between Windows 10 and Xbox One.[72]
Chris Metzen announced his departure from Blizzard Entertainment.[73]
15-18 Tokyo Game Show was held and celebrated its 20th Anniversary

28 Ubisoft acquired Ketchapp, the developer of 2048.[75]
October 12-13 Steam Dev Days held in Seattle, Washington.[76]
17 United Front Games, the developer of Sleeping Dogs, shut down.[77]
20 Nintendo publicly announces its next home console, the Switch.[78]
21 The Screen Actors Guild‐American Federation of Television and Radio Artists begins a strike against eleven American video game developers and publishers over payments of residuals to voice and motion capture artists in video games.[79]
25 The Tomb Raider franchise celebrated its 20th anniversary.
November 4-5 BlizzCon 2016 held in Anaheim, California.[80]
December 1 Annapurna Pictures establish gaming division Annapurna Interactive.[81]
The Game Awards 2016 held in Los Angeles, California.
3–4 PlayStation Experience 2016 held in Anaheim, California.
16 Shinji Hirano, the former president of Konami Europe, became the CEO of Kojima Productions.[82]
20 Atlus formed a new development studio called Studio Zero.[83]
Crytek closed its studio in Bulgaria, Hungary, Turkey, South Korea, and China.[84]

Highly scoring games released in 2016 with fewer than 10 reviews include Out of the Park Baseball 17, Stephen's Sausage Roll, Kentucky Route Zero - Act IV, Axiom Verge, and Keep Talking and Nobody Explodes.[777]
